title: Basic Issues in Intercultural Studies
requirements: For students in MA Intercultural Studies or MA Visual Culture Studies
description: This course explores the core areas of (inter)cultural studies.Topics such as media culture, consumer culture, theme parks, cityscapes, spectacle society, cyberculture and technoscience culture will be discussed. Again, emphasis will be given to Hong Kong culture as a basic reference point in its contact and interaction with other cultures.

title: Modern Urbanscape and Asian Culture
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management, MA in Visual Culture Studies and MA in Intercultural Studies
description: As cultural melting-pots, cosmopolitan cities around Asia provide some excellent case studies on the relationship between interculturalism and the urbanity of megacities in the world. The question of cultural identity - a plurality of selves - will be explored through a comparative study of the varies urban centres in Asia. The emphasis of study is on the ways how music, literature, TV, film, and technoscape and mediascape (themselves being a mixture of Asian, American and European components) are related to Asia's unique location and its many overcrowded, mishmash, disjunctive cityscape.
outcome: This course would enable students to: - conceptualise the problematics of space and the city - reflect on urban crisis Asia faces against the background of global capitalism  - interrogate discourses on development and modernisation

title: The Body in Culture and Art
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: Images of the body represent systems of thought, aesthetics beauty and our identity. This course takes a comparative approach to theories of body and embodiment in the Western and the Chinese traditions. In this course we will ask: What is a body? How do we define and represent different bodies? In what ways do cultural values mold our perception of the body? How is the understanding of the body informed and transformed by scientific development? Throughout this course we will seek answers to these questions by focusing on the Western and the Chinese traditions from the cultural and the scientific perspectives. We will analyse some important themes of the subject by integrating a theoretical approach with art, photography, films, novels and short stories.

title: Cultural Studies in Film and Video
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: Cinema is one of the most important forms of representations in contemporary culture, and in this course we study film and video from the perspective of cultural studies. The course is not aimed at teaching students basic skills of textual and image analysis, but we read cinema culturally and politically. We want to examine how the cultural forms of moving images carry meanings, and how it can and cannot be used as ideological apparatus. Through the studies of film and video we also trace the development of contemporary visual culture and examine how it defines (post)modern lives and experience. Studying through the history of moving images, this course provides students a general theoretical landscape to understand and criticize our contemporary mass representations. Our ultimate aim is to interrogate the boundaries and to locate new terrains between cinema studies and cultural studies.
outcome: This course aims to help students conduct cultural studies in film and video by discussing both the seminal literature of visual culture and East Asian cinema, with a particular emphasis on how cultural imagination and transnational flows of various kinds shape contemporary cinema in terms of its production and narrative structures. Students are also expected to learn to use basic film language to understand the core issues of engaging in cultural studies in film and video with a critical perspective and a cross-disciplinary methodology. This seminar consists of class lectures, oral presentations, discussions and film viewings.

title: The Culture of Travel and the Travel of Culture
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: Travel has recently become a complex phenomenon of unprecedented proportions. Whereas people travel and bring themselves into contact with other peoples and other cultures, cultures themselves also travel to different places and societies. Through an interdisciplinary approach, this course provides a theoretical and historical framework to analyse and reflect upon the relationships between travel and culture with the concerns of globalization, consumption, people and places.

title: Gender, Love and Sexuality in Intercultural Studies
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course aims at enhancing consciousness of the variations among humans in their sexualities and more accepting of individuals with sexualities different than your own. To accomplish this we will examine a number of variations with a sympathetic perspective without regard to their acceptability within the current cultural perspectives of our society. Students are encouraged to examine their sexuality in both critical and sympathetic ways incorporating the insights gained in the course.
outcome:  Critical awareness related to issues pertaining to gender, racial, class, and national identities  Ability in critically analyzing the diversity of values and interests in society  Inter-cultural sensitivity and respect

title: Interdisciplinary Study of Technoscience Culture
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course explores the impact of the worldwide technoscience revolution of our era in the cultural context. We are in the midst of the fast developments of technology and science. As witness to this important moment, we have a vantage point to review the cultural impact of technology on social, economic, political development over the past two centuries. As there is now a surge of feminist studies of science and technology, special emphasis will be given to the interrelationship between gender and technoscience.

title: Adaptations, Theatre and Culture
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course looks at theatre as an intercultural transference, “a unique machinery for overcoming cultural differences and reaching out towards other cultures.” It examines plays and productions, original and in translation, from theoretical and practical, literary and theatrical perspectives. The concern is not only with how the text is translated but also how new meanings are created against a local cultural environment, such as Hong Kong. Students will attend some local and visiting productions in the theatre.

description: The specific topics of this course vary from year to year. Generally, they can be genres, systems of representation, cultural forms, issues and/or theories related to the dynamic process of interactivity among cultures.

title: Globalization and the Politics of Representation
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: Globalization has become a key term in the analysis of contemporary society and culture. This course will trace the development of the concept across different disciplines and theoretical paradigms, review socio-economic and cultural accounts of globalization, study artistic production, and examine counter-discourses and social movements against globalization. Throughout the course, we will interrogate the politics of representation around globalization, questioning specifi cally the grounds on which global claims are made; the categories, processes, and practices foregrounded and occluded; the voices privileged, heard and silenced; and the kinds of subjectivities and collective identities enabled and produced in globalization discourses.
outcome: Students are expected to develop interdisciplinary perspectives to understand and be critical of the following:  Our regional, national, and global orders are made up of and maintained by cultural practices, expressions, and meanings.  Cultural production, circulation, and consumption are ideologically and economically linked.  Students are expected to develop the following skills and values:  Inter-cultural sensitivity and respect  A balance of local and global perspectives  Ability in critically analyzing the diversity of values and interests in society

title: Media and Popular Culture
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course introduces students to the critical study of media theory and popular culture, and its socio-cultural impacts on everyday life, society and geopolitics. It emphasizes the study of history, production, genre, social reception and political effect of various kinds of cultural products such as advertisement, photography, comics, television and VCD technology, popular music and MTV, newspaper and printing culture, computer and internet. The course’s objective is to acquaint students with different methodologies in media theory, and encourage them to examine the media text from the perspectives of semiotics, ideological criticism, gender representation and cultural policy. We also focus on the analysis and evaluation of popular culture in relation to the formation of capitalism, the rise of mass media, the commercialization of culture, lifestyle and leisure in comparative perspective.

title: Politics of Cultural Identities
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course dwells on various topics in the field of cultural identities, from its historical origin and theoretical ground in the West, to its contemporary phenomena and ramifications across the globe, ranging from Europe, North America, to Chinese and local contexts. The course ends with a discussion of the situation in post-colonial Hong Kong.

title: Queer Movements and Sexual Politics
requirements: For students in MA Intercultural Studies, MA Cultural Management and MA Visual Culture Studies
description: The last two decades witness the rise of vibrant new social movements in the field of sexuality, which, together with many other intersecting social forces, has tremendously reshaped the socio-political landscapes, here and abroad. This course aims to examine the historical trajectory of queer movements as well as the issues and debates pertinent to them so as to make sense of the complexity of sexual politics in the late modern society. It also poses challenges to the commonly held division between academy and social activism by examining their intertwined but not very smooth relationship. To that end, the course will draw on the works of lesbian and gay historians such as Lillian Faderman, Jeffrey Weeks, John D’Emilio and Michel Foucault to lay a social constructionist framework through which the emergence of polymorphous sexual subjects is understood. The social construction of homosexuality in Hong Kong since the 1980s will be discussed as a case in point. The works of Diana Fuss, Judith Butler and Eve Segewick will guide us to explore the internal dilemma of identity politics and the queer turn in the study of sexuality.
outcome: 1. To acquire a deeper theoretical understanding of the role sexuality plays in the late modern society and its socio-political implications 2. To develop an ability to critically integrate mutli-disciplinary perspectives and intervene into intellectual debates of significance to sexuality 3. To appreciate the interconnectedness between academy and social changes 4. To appreciate the importance of close reading

title: Digital Culture and Society
requirements: For students in MA Intercultural Studies, MA Cultural Management and MA Visual Culture Studies
description: The course focuses on the correlation between culture and technology in the contemporary society. The rise of the information age has brought about categorical changes in social expressions, cultural productions and personal identities. The course will begin a contextual discussion on the advent of the digital age and its impact on traditional media. Thereafter, the course will look into how technology affects the understanding of the trends and developments of a variety of topics related to the contemporary society, such as human rights (including the rights of LGBT), citizen journalism (and public shaming), independent films and documentaries, visual and performing arts, and cultural heritage. The course will conclude with an exploration on how digital media has affected the practices of social work, especially in youth work.
outcome: At the end of the course, students will be able to: - Understand the concept of the network society and how technology shapes and are shaped by social and cultural factors - Develop the critical and analytical skills in interpreting the theoretical debates and approaches surrounding digital culture and its impact on contemporary society and human practices - Make sense of their roles in society as cultural studies students, through practice-based work, in the digital age.

title: Practical & Critical Film Criticism Writing
requirements: For students in MA Intercultural Studies, MA Cultural Management and MA Visual Culture Studies
description: This course will focus on introducing the various theories, methods and practices of writing film criticism, regarding especially narrative films. It aims to achieve three particular goals: 1. to introduce to students different methods and techniques of film criticism, including the humanist, auteurist, genre, social science, historical, and aesthetics analyses of film texts, in order to understand the distinct history and development of each of these theoretical schools; 2. to acquire the skill to read film texts against their specific discursive background, and to dissect, deconstruct and critique the ideology behind the cinematic images; and 3. to learn to integrate one’s cinematic experience in terms of emotion and reason, and to develop one’s unique style in writing film critiques for recent films in popular magazines. In the course of teaching, three aspects will be highlighted including the critical, functional and practical aspects, and students’ ability for critical exchanges and practical writing training in film criticism will be emphasized. As much as possible, local film critics will be invited to share with students their writing experience in class.

title: Chinese Society, Culture and Politics
requirements: For students of MA in Intercultural Studies, MA in Cultural Management and MA in Visual Culture Studies
description: This course aims to think through some of the contradictions and issues concerning developmental transition, culture and politics in mainland Chinese society through texts on cultural theories, Chinese studies, local and oversea. The course is divided into three sections. The first reviews cultural debates and social concerns in the late 70s and 80s of China. The second investigates the emergence of sharp inequalities arising from developmental contradictions, class stratification and the intellectual debates surrounding these issues. Last the course looks at the latest studies on topics such as new religions, ethnic conflicts, middle class desires and the web media in contemporary China.

title: Cross-Dressing and Hong Kong Cinema
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: In her “Imitation and Gender Insubordination,” Judith Butler initiates her concept of “gender performativity.” She proclaims that gender is a drag, and it is an imitation and a performance that produces the illusion of an inner sex or psychic gender core. In other words, gender and sexuality is the production of “self” structured and motivated by various kinds of sociopolitical, cultural, racial and historical forces. Engaging the configuration of gender, sexual identity and body politics by Butler as well as other queer theorists such as Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick, Judith Halberstam, Mary Ann Doane and Marjorie Garber, this course is designed to investigate the cross-dressing and the gender-crossing of Hong Kong cinema in comparison with Western filmmaking. We will study the cross-dressers and their visual representations in both Chinese and Western cinema. Issues addressed include the historical construction of cross-dressing, the redefinition of masculinity and femininity of transvestites, the queer spectatorship of audience reception, gay and lesbian identities, homophobia and heterosexism, transsexualism and the discourse of AIDS. What we are going to interrogate is how clothes make gender and sexuality in cinematic representation and stage performance especially in martial arts genre and opera film.

title: Culture and Politics in the Anthropocene
requirements: For students in MA in Intercultural Studies, MA in Cultural Management or MA in Visual Culture Studies
description: The idea of the Anthropocene – the geological Age of Man – has become widely adopted as a way of describing the entanglement of human activities and the natural world after its popularization by Paul Crutzen in 2000. In the age of the Anthropocene, challenges arising from global environmental change are numerous: extreme weather, land and water pollution, species extinction, toxic contamination, just to name a few. These challenges are now raising concerns both from scholars in the natural science and from the humanities and the social sciences. This course works on a rapidly growing field of Enviornmental Humanities constituted by the work of scholars from a wide variety of disciplines including history, literature, philosophy, cultural studies, religion studies, arts.It aims to provide students with some recent methodological and theoretical approaches of understanding the anthropocene, including cultural ecology, environmental history, science studies, poststructuralist cultural studies, and eco-feminism. Envisioning the field as a trandisciplinary arena, the course will foster students to think across disciplinary borders in order to tackle the environmental and social challenges of current times.

title: Animals and Society
requirements: For students in MA in Intercultural Studies, MA in Cultural Management or MA in Visual Culture Studies
description: Cultural studies has sustained concern on everyday life with mass production, consumerism, sexism, racism and postmodernism, but the discipline is always thought to be lagging behind the concern of nature and animal. Nevertheless, as the issues of animal abuse, environmental protection, factory farming, protection policy, law-making and media portrayals of animals are the hot topics in our (post)modern culture, the study of animal with the perspective of cultural studies and other humanity disciplines can explore the possibilities of an advanced human-animal relationship. This course is designed with an empathic concern of other-than-human animals. By exploring different issues of human and animals’ life, this course looks for a harmonious balance of nature and modern culture.
outcome: On successful completion of the course, students are expected to be able to:  1. Explain the concern of other-than-human animal with cultural studies perspective; 2. Identify the key issues and critical assessment of human-animal relationship; 3. Understand the approach in studying culture, animal and environment; 4. Enrich the angle of analyzing human living and animal species.
syllabus: This course focuses on three areas, through which we can explore the different aspects of animal and cultural studies. These areas are: A. Entering Jurassic World – Remaking Animals in Leisure (Lecture A1-A4) B. Attacking Godzilla – Representing Animals in Media (Lecture B1-B4) C. Leaving Zootopia – Revitalizing Animals in the City (Lecture C1-C4) Each area covers a set of animal issue discussion. Area A, apart from theorizing animal with cultural studies, tackles the basic animal issues: pet-nurturing, zoo-building, forest-sustaining and tourism. This is to provide a foundation for understanding animals with a critical reflection of everyday life.   Area B, set with the concern of media, discusses issues of animal representation in animation, cinema, literature and journalism. This is to read how animals would be represented and how this affects human understanding and related policy-making.   Area C further deals with the matters of animal-city relationship in seeing how dogs and cats, cattle and swine, and fishes and dolphins are (mal)treated in the street, the farm and the sea respectively. This is to end the course with a leading thought of perfect balance of nature and modernity; and more queries of human-animal relationship will be raised for contemplation.

title: Discourse on Hong Kong, Hong Kong Discourse
requirements: For students in MA in Intercultural Studies, MA in Cultural Management or MA in Visual Culture Studies
description: This course is designed to study Hong Kong from the perspectives of HK discourses formed in the past decades, with emphasis on the post-1997 context, where we witness the proliferation of HK discourses consolidating, contesting or displacing each other incessantly. In this course we will examine them in both breadth and depth; topics discussed include (post)coloniality, transborder, city and space awareness, variegated localism, China factor, cosmopolitanism, mega-region, generation, social movement, etc. While the topics are not in strict chronological order and each has a narrative of its own, they are unfolded in a sequence that overall form a historical picture of Hong Kong and its discourse formation. For each topic, students will be introduced with theoretical concepts, narrative and representations involved. Students will also get to know some key scholars involved in the discussion. Not shun from taking position, students are encouraged to keep open-minded and evaluate the issues critically, particularly to treat the discourses as ongoing process rather than static products. While we focus on one topic per week for explication purpose, students should note the intricate relationship among the related topics, and keep in mind to build the linkage and dialogue among them.

title: The Chinese Independent Film Studies
requirements: For MA in Cultural Management or MA in Intercultural Studies
description: Since 1989, the independent film has become the unique window to understand the real China beyond the national mainstream discourse and state-controlled film industry. The content of independent films reflects the various social problems and cultural phenomena confronting contemporary China in its rapid economic development. This course, in surveying its development of the past three decades, strives to describe the changes of the internal environment of the independent film’s circles, explore the aesthetic characteristics as well as, politics, ethics and techniques of the Chinese independent film.
outcome: -To equip students with general knowledge of the concepts and the history of the Chinese independent film.-To analyze the close connection between history and culture in the Chinese independent film.-To build up the ability of independent thinking when dealing with the social culture problems and issues. -After completing the course successfully, students would be able to read and analyze deeply in diverse ways of critical thinking on a single film or a group of films, such as the views of genre, auteurship, and spectatorship, etc. Attitude Outcomes:-Aware of multicultural communities and respect for the other-Being confident in expressing ones ideas-Board-minded but strong in critical evaluation

title: Concepts of Contemporary Culture
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management, MA in Visual Culture Studies and MA in Intercultural Studies
description: This course looks into basic theoretical perspectives and areas of interests in cultural studies. At the knowledge level, this core course is to survey in some detail how the cultural turn in humanities and social sciences helps us understand everyday life in a fresh way, for example ways in which we are being constructed and reshaped by our experience of everyday life, as well as the embedded values (in financial terms and ethical terms) are being forged and circulated explicitly and implicitly. This course seeks to encourage among students attitude of openness to new ideas and learning creatively through living.
outcome: • Become acquainted with the basic issues of contemporary culture; • Understand the perspectives of interdisciplinary in cultural studies; • Realize to discuss cultural and social issues in critical ways; • Understand the key theoretical concepts in cultural studies.

title: Introduction to Managing Non-Profit Organizations
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: The course aims to introduce concepts, theories and practices of various management issues in non-profit organizations including strategic management, human resources management, financial management, PR & Marketing management, management ethics etc. Students will be introduced to analyze and understand management issues through both theories and case studies. Application of management concepts and principles in non-profit organizations will be highlighted. Students are encouraged to evaluate the concepts and principles to their work environments and/or areas of interest in the arts and cultural industry.

title: Visual Arts Administration
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management
description: The visual arts in Hong Kong have long been neglected: artists complain that their works have not been properly interpreted and presented while spectators rarely derive enjoyment from their viewing experiences. The aim of the course is to explore this bleak situation by taking a closer look at the administration of visual arts in Hong Kong; after all, the arts administrators serve as the bridge between artists and the general public. Certain questions needed to be asked such as given the current available resources, have these administrators been doing their best? Experts from local major institutions will be invited to share their views, experiences, mission and objectives with the students so that a fuller picture of the administration of the visual arts in Hong Kong can be created.
outcome: • Basic Concepts of managing various types of visual arts institutions• Basic Principles of managing visual arts institutions and the organization of various types of art projects• Understand the global and local cultural ecology, especially the scene in Hong Kong• Engage in a critical review of format and practice of visual arts management
syllabus: Course Content1. Introduction   This class gives an introduction to the profession of visual arts management, the roles, functions, operational structures and modes of governance of various types of visual art spaces (museum, gallery, commercial gallery, artists’ co-op, community art space, etc.) in a contemporary society.2. Exhibition space: Historical Development  This session traces the historical development of art gallery, museum and other exhibition space, study how the development of new social and cultural trends in post-industrial society affect the operation of visual arts management. 3. Institutional Identity, Building and Services This session looks into two related areas: the identity and the architectural configuration of an art institution. The identity relates to the vision, mission as well as mandate of the institution, it also gives shape to its institutional culture. The architectural configuration reflects not only the artistic identity, but also services provided and curatorial thinking behind the institution. The session will also covers alternative space, evaluating its strength, weakness and possibilities.4. Exhibition Programming and Operation The session investigates the managerial support required for exhibition programming, including the operational procedures in actualizing programmes, drafting of proposal, operational plan, budgeting and schedule, as well as other supporting events such as exhibition opening.5. Funding and Resources Building  With reduction of government funding and increasing competition, art institutions are desperate in seeking funding. This session looks into various types of funding sources, ranging from government grant, corporate sponsorship to private donation, and investigates different ways of building self-generated fund and some of the creative ways of seeking new resources.6. Marketing and Publicity Increasingly marketing becomes an important part in cultural management in helping to increase audience and support. The session studies the work of marketing and publicity of cultural institutions, which are different from business marketing and relies heavily on free advertising. Emphasis is given to the practical skills in undertaking effective promotion and publicity in relationship wit the vision and missions of the institution.7. Education and Outreach Activities   This session focuses on the planning and organization of various types of education programmes, from school programme to programme for general public and special community groups. The class also discusses outreaching programme and audience building programme.8. Art and urban development  This session studies how the new waves in cultural tourism and creative affects the development of art, and how globalization shapes the physical and cultural language of the non-Western districts.9. Planning Museum Focusing on the setting up of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Shanghai and the planning of M+ at the West Kowloon Cultural District, this session focuses on the planning of a cultural space and study the various procedures involved, including both the practical as well as the conceptual work.  10. Fieldtrip 11. Crisis Management and Professional Ethics   This session discusses the design and management of the venue, provision of various types of public services an art institution provides, the sensibility and the ethical conduct required, and some of the problematic issues such as ‘admission charge’ that emerge. It also studies the creative solutions in dealing with accidents and crisis in the presentation and conservation of art objects.12. Local Art Scene and Future Development  This session looks into the local visual art scene, the cultural policy and ecology that are affecting the development of art, the challenges and possibility during the post 1997 era.13. Review This session will give an overall review to the course, answer enquires and discuss issues raised related to the course and the final paper.

title: Performing Arts Administration
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management
description: The aims of the course are to examine the relationship between the performing arts and the community, the evolution and main players of arts policy in Hong Kong, and for students to gain general understanding of the many facets of performing arts administration and be able to discuss related issues with some insights and to learn basic skills in performing arts administration. It covers topics on performing arts administration, including an introduction of arts policy and development of arts provision in Hong Kong, current arts infrastructure in Hong Kong, planning and organizational structure, audience development and arts education, sponsorship and fundraising, etc.
outcome: • Critically evaluate and to interpret accurately the various business and management processes, procedures and practices in the understanding of the importance of performing arts management.• Understand the different approaches to managing non-profit and for-profit performing arts events/organizations.• Understand and communicate the entrepreneurial approaches in developing the integrated marketing communication strategies of a performing arts event/organization.• Critically assess the relationship between the artist and the community.• Critically evaluate how policies, audience and education affect performing arts administration.

title: Museum and Archives Studies
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course introduces students to different methodologies and materials significant in studying the past, and in particular, the usefulness of combining both textual and non- textual materials in analysing the history, environment, and culture of our local communities. The course will be team-taught by specialists who focus on both the theory and practice of historical preservation. Students will learn about the concepts and methods concerning doing fieldwork, conducting oral history, analysing archaeological artifacts and remains, collecting and exhibiting Hong Kong’s material culture in local museums, preserving historical architecture, and making use of archival studies in China and Hong Kong.
outcome: • To let students re-think, re-consider and re-define a museum’s roles, functions, values and meanings–––through the introduction of alternative museum concepts. After completing this module, students are expected to develop new theories, visions and insights, and their own methodologies in research. • Students are encouraged to develop an independent thinking, analytical mind and perceive things from different perspectives, such skills and knowledge could be applicable to their own and/or other disciplines.  • Students are expected to acquire basic concepts, theories and knowledge in managing a museum and an archives. They are encouraged to widen their scope and area of interests in museum-archives-related aspects, and to extend such interests and knowledge to their own and/or other fields.

title: Cultural Development and Policy
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: The course will serve as an introduction to the nature, function and limits of cultural policy, with particular reference to the Hong Kong context. The policy issues discussed in this course include: the relationship between Government and the arts; the democratisation of culture and cultural democracy; the economic importance of the arts; cultural diversity; the impact of sponsorship; and, cultural policy and popular culture.
outcome: • Demonstrate an understanding of key concepts and issues in cultural policy • Comprehend the development of cultural policy with reference to international experience • Critically reflect on the value and uses of arts and culture  • Identify dissonances between rhetoric and practice within the cultural sector • Engage in intellectual debates on related topics with rigorous evidence support and communicate both orally and in writing • Formulate informed strategies for their art and culture related work or career

title: Film/Video and Media Art Administration
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management
description: The first part of this course will identify and discuss certain key movements in the history of the Hollywood film industry from the 1890s to the 1950s. In the second part of the course, we will investigate the impact of the international circulation of films and the complicated and contested global dominance of Hollywood with reference to the development of the Hong Kong film industry and its specific socio-political context. Finally we will discuss the increasing frequency of international co-production as a means to maintain viable national film production with international appeal and the impact of postmodernism and globalization on film production and aesthetics.
outcome: • understand the different natures and characteristics of film, video and new media arts.• have the knowledge about the development of Hong Kong independent cinema, plus a quick glimpse of the film industry on sales and distribution.• acquire basic administrative, creative programming and curatorship knowledge on moving images• critically assess the execution of a film/video and media arts programme/ festival.• write a professional proposal for a film/video and media arts project

title: Graduate Research Paper
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management
description: Research on an approved topic for writing a graduation paper under individualized supervision. Consent of teacher required.
outcome: • Demonstrate specialist knowledge in an area of Cultural Management. • Demonstrate the ability to formulate viable research questions, review literature, identify and implement research methodologies. • Demonstrate the ability to evaluate results and present findings at a Master level.

title: Xiqu and Performing Culture
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: In Hong Kong popular culture, Xiqu (sometimes know as Chinese Opera) is used as a symbol of “China” in advertisement, theatre and other kinds of performing arts. This course is aimed at introducing the essential artistic elements of Xiqu and analyzing different kinds of mutations and transformations in practicing. We will study the challenges and junctures when Xiqu meets the other art-form. Also we will use Cantonese Opera as an example to probe into the linkage between local culture and the characteristics of different Xiqu culture in different perspectives, including gender, nationality and ritual.
outcome: • Understand the nature of Xiqu and its practice, make sense of their roles, and the possible contributions to the civil society • Critically review the rapid developments of key elements within the civil society, through synthesizing different theories and contexts of the digital age. • Undertake and realize an actual project (of students’ interest) to effectively participate in the civil society.

title: Curatorship
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management.;Students are required to have taken CULS5307 before they could take this course. Exception can be made if evidence of previous working experience in visual arts management is provided.
description: One of the most challenging aspects of visual arts management is the practice of curatorship. With the rapid global growth of museums and the popularity of the biennale culture, curatorial interpretation has become an infl uential force in shaping the defi nition of art and museum. This course nurtures students’ creative and interpretive skills in conceiving and developing curatorial ideas, equips students with the technical, managerial and communicative skills in planning, organizing and interpreting exhibitions. It also introduces a critical study of practice of curatorship, reviewing its traditions, limitations and possibilities for abuses and development. - Prerequisite course(s): CULS5307. Exception can be made if evidence of previous working experience in visual arts management is provided.
outcome: • Basic approaches to art appreciation and analysis; • Over all understanding of the curatorial practice, from generating curatorial ideas to the final implementation; • Creative thinking, both creative and intellectual, in conceiving curatorial ideas; • Technical and managerial skills in implementing various types of exhibitions;  • Critical review in the practice, cultural values and ethics of curatorship.

title: Exhibition Design and Installation
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management;Students are required to have taken CULS5307 before they could take this course. Exception can be made if evidence of previous working experience in visual arts management is provided.
description: Exhibition design is a highly specialized profession that requires technical skills, artistic sensibility, creativity and flexibility in dealing with the complicated demands of a broad range of art forms. This course informs students of the aesthetic and technical requirement for articulating curatorial concepts through the design and installation of exhibitions. It also intends to equip students with the basic technical know-how in designing and setting up various types of exhibition, and the studies of environmental and security control within an exhibition space. In addition to the technical training, the course will, through the study of the evolution of exhibition design, investigate how the design of exhibition affects the interpretation of art, and review the cultural values and ideologies hidden behind the various formats of exhibition display.Students are required to have taken CULS5307 before they could take this course. Exception can be made if evidence of previous working experience in visual arts management is provided.

title: Special Topics in Cultural Management
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: The specific topics of this course vary from year to year. It will focus each time on a specific area or an issue of cultural management that is not covered in the regular courses of the cultural management programme. It aims to enrich the programme with topics concerning cutting edge issues in cultural policy, cultural industries and their management. Because the theme of this course changes from year to year, students are allowed to take this course more than once (not within the same term), and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take the same topic twice.
outcome: • Critically identify, interpret and evaluate the operational issues in running a small arts organization. • Apply the foundations of administrative theories to analyse production, procedures technical processes, trends and practices in running a small arts organization. • Evaluate and strengths and weaknesses of small arts organization in society. • Develop and implement strategies through group-based work.

title: Curating and Managing Cultural Festivals
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management;Pre-requisite: CULS5308;Exception can be made if evidence of previous working experience in visual arts management is provided.
description: In order to attract public participation and media attention, cultural institutions are giving more emphasis to organizing large scale cultural programmes such as biennales, arts festivals and multi-disciplinary events. Organizing such mega projects involves huge budget, complicated technical arrangement, large number of staff, artists and diversified progrmames. The course studies not only the organization, management and promotion of the various types of large scale cultural presentations, ranging from thematic arts festivals, multi-disciplinary projects, public entertainment, community arts projects to celebrative events, but also nurtures students’ curatorial capability in identifying, developing and implementing programmes for these mega-cultural projects. Students are required to have taken CULS 5308 before they could take this course. Exception can be made if evidence of previous working experience in performing arts management is provided.
outcome: • Critically evaluate and to interpret accurately the various business and management processes, procedures and practices in the organizing of cultural festivals. • Understand and communicate clear programming philosophies/design of arts festivals. • Critically assess the relationship between cultural festivals and their communities, places and other sociocultural impacts. • Understand the philosophy and management style of major international and local arts festivals. • Organize an actual arts festival from scratch, with specific focus on artists liaison, marketing and administration.

title: Practicums
requirements: For students in MA Cultural Management
description: Students are encouraged to gain practical experience through this programme. Every year the Department will identify appropriate projects and inform students normally at least one month before the beginning of school term for application. A selection process is required as opportunity from this programme is limited. Based on the nature of projects. specially designed schemes will be worked out with the students and a supervisor will be assigned. Final evaluation is based on supervisor’s evaluation and project reports by the students.
outcome: Career Awareness  • Apply academic knowledge in real life situations and a professional environment. • Develop comprehensive knowledge of arts and cultural management, specifically procedures of organising and implementing arts programmes, events or festivals. • Gain insight from inception to completion: planning, curating, financing, staffing, marketing, staging and evaluating. • Observe how an arts organisation operates and functions. • Learn how a certain job functions in an organisation. • Build a professional network.  Knowledge, Competencies and Skills • Develop professional skills: appropriate workplace attitudes, analytical capacity and problem solving skills, interpersonal and public communication skills, research and analytical skills. • Learn how to relate co-workers effectively and contribute to a team environment. • Help build the ability to work independently, and to initiate and foster organisational and leadership skills. • Gain an understanding of professional etiquette. • Gain added knowledge and skills such as computer proficiency, social networking and website management through work experience.

title: Cultural Venues Management
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: Cultural events have to be presented in a venue of some kind, be it a theatre, an arena, a museum or a particular “site”. A well-run venue makes planned activities more effective and the lives of all its stakeholders easier. An ill-run venue can actually defeat the very purpose of its existence. This course aims to impart the best venue management practices and introduce the latest technologies to middle and line managers, to improve their work, their careers and the buildings they associate with.
outcome: The course is designed to enable students to take an effective role in the operation and management of any performing venues after completing the course. Students will learn about the current and best practices for all the essential aspects of such venues, such as: - Corporate Governance - Venue Branding - Customer Services - Crowd Control & Security - Information Provision - Stage Technical Services - Repairs, maintenance, alternations, improvement and development
syllabus: Week 1 Students will learn of the rudiments of theatre management. Students will also learn to identify the stakeholders of a performing arts venue – users, customers, management, workers, owners, and also their particular bias and missions.  Week 2 A visit to a theatre for the understanding of the basic set up, architectural space and essential facilities in relationship with theatrical presentation and audience reception.  Week 3 Students’ presentations and discussion on the set up, facilities, functional efficiency and potential problems of various aspects of the theatre visited, and look into possible solutions of improvement.  Week 4 This session studies maintenance, repairs, alternations, improvement and extensional development of a theatre building. Discussion with practicing specialist from the field may be arranged.  Week 5 This session focuses on the stage technical services, its operation and equipment involved. Discussion with practicing specialist from the field may be arranged.  Week 6 This session involves another field-trip to a theatre of different scale and set up for a broader understanding of the differences in the building and operation of a theatre.   Week 7 & Week 8 This session includes talks and presentations on customer services, crowd control, security, information provision, and a study of the inter-relatedness of these various services and operations. Discussion with practicing specialist from the field may be arranged.  Week 9 A visit to a performing space of different components and operational structure to further study the various forms of performing arts presentations.  Week 10 Students will give presentation on the venue set up and operation of the third theatre visited, and discusses their ideas on the possibilities of improvement, based on what the course has so far covered.  Week 11 This session studies the strategies and planning of venue branding and the various models of venue governance, and to study how these set-ups affect the operation of the building.  Week 12 Students will form study groups and visit different venues according to the choice of their groups, and prepare their final presentations, which involve an in-depth studies of the various aspects of the management of performing arts venue.  Week 13 Concluding presentations, discussion and review.

title: Formation and Operation of Small Arts Organizations
requirements: This course is offered to students of MA in Intercultural Studies, MA in Cultural Management and MA in Visual Culture Studies.
description: Small arts organizations face a range of operational challenges, such as the lack of government and corporate funding, multi-tasking due to inadequate manpower resources, cash flow issues, technical know-how etc. At times, the works of small arts organizations are deemed as raw and their artistic quality pales in comparison with professional arts organizations. In major cities worldwide, including Hong Kong, the mechanistic structure and the high barriers of entry (not unlike a meritocracy) of professional arts organizations have encouraged the rise small arts organizations. Despite the small size, such organizations have great potential to play an important role in the development of arts and culture. This course seeks to explore unique issues in the operations of small arts organizations, and to offer solutions from various cultural management perspectives.

title: Concept and Practice of Community Arts
requirements: For MA in Cultural Management, MA in Intercultural Studies and MA in Visual Culture Studies
description: Community arts emerged as an important alternative arts form since the 1960s and have become increasingly recognized for its importance. It is a distinctive arts form that is highly different from the conventional forms of cultural management. Engaging with artists, social workers and most importantly with members of various communities, creative projects are organized with the intention to animate and power the underprivileged and the marginal. The course gives a basic introduction to the history, philosophy, practicing techniques as well as the ethical issues related to community arts for future involvement in an arts form that reconnects arts with the community and uses arts for individual and communal improvement.
outcome: Learning Outcomes 1. An understanding of the objectives, philosophy and ethical concerns; 2. Learning of the technical skills in organizing and monitoring community arts; 3. Nurturing creative skills in curating community arts projects dealing with specific community and issues.  At the end of the course, students will be able to  1. Understand the nature of community arts, its history and its various schools of thoughts; 2. Able to take the initiative of organizing events responding to community needs;
syllabus: Week & Content 1. Public arts, arts at public space and community arts. - An introduction to three types of arts forms that go outside of conventional artistic space and move into the public sphere, focusing on the missions, visions, operational structure, similarities and differences. 2. Community arts: its history, evolutions. - This section studies the history of various arts forms that serve and work with the communities, and trace the evolutions of community arts through history. 3. Basic concept of community arts - The session introduces some of the key concepts and principles guiding the operation of community arts, such as inclusiveness, empowerment and animation. 4. Community arts in Hong Kong - This session traces the history of community arts in Hong Kong since the 1980s, and the social and political happenings that lead to its rapid development in the last decade. 5. Community arts organization in Hong Kong  - An over-all review of some of the main players practicing community arts in Hong Kong, studying their missions, areas of focus and impacts. 6. Key topic in community arts  - Community arts frequently deal with some specific issues, such as environmental and heritage preservation, cultural rights, identity building, equality, etc., this session takes an overall view of these key topics and studies the appropriate approaches required. 7. Key activities - Once identifying the issues, different artistic methods and approaches will be adopted to achieve goals, this session focuses on different ways of project implementation, including through theatre, dance, visual arts and other forms of artistic/cultural expressions. 8. Case studies I: International - This session studies some important international projects to show the diversity and creativity in organizing community arts, the cases are also important stimulation for students in planning community arts.  9. Case studies II: Asia ⁻ Focusing on cases in Asia (including Hong Kong), this session studies some distinctive projects within Asian context to look into the different cultural and technical approaches in community arts. 10. Workshop in community arts ⁻ Practicing artist in community arts will be invited to organize workshop for practical learning of doing group exercise in community arts. 11. Ethical issues in community arts ⁻ As community arts deals with the underprivileged and the marginal, sensibility is essential when organizing these activities, this session focuses on the ethical and critical dimension of working in community arts.  12. Fieldtrip - Visit to an organization or a site where community arts is being organized and engage students in dialogue with the community arts practitioners. 13. Review and discussion ⁻ Final review and discussion over critical issues in community arts.

title: Film/Video Production & Presentation
requirements: For MA in Cultural Management or MA in Intercultural Studies
description: With the development of technologies, contemporary filmmaking has become faster and flexible. This practical course is designed for storytellers who want to translate their ideas into compelling videos. Though pre-production, filming, to post-production, students will learn the visual-audio language, basic skills and techniques of filmmaking, including camera shooting, sound recording, lighting, editing by using Adobe Premiere and After Effect, etc. It consists of lectures, readings, screenings and consultations, hands-on visual projects and mini workshops; helps students to explore their conceptual and aesthetic styles in the end.

Students are supposed to organize a screening to show their own works in the end of the semester.  6. To learn how to spread and distribute video works.

title: Contemporary Arts & Cultural Interactivity
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course will study the cultural forms of contemporary art biennales, culural precincts and the ‘architecture’ of contemporary art as a network. The aim of the course is to introduce students to the general framework of global cultural circuits, exchange and interactivity with a study of the dynamic processes of cultural change and exchange. Comparisons between institutional structures of cultural administration (and administrative culture) on the one hand and more dynamic networks of cultural fl ows on the other, will be explored via close attention to the rhetoric of policy formation and the emergence of cultural centres, precincts and institutions globally.
outcome: To explain the development of contemporary art genres and artistic technologies locally and globally. To identify the key characteristics of post-formalist art forms and dialogic aesthetics within contemporary art. To discuss particular artists and artworks, using the discourses of art and cultural criticism. To apply ethnographic research methods to observe and study the work of contemporary artists and to initiate exchanges with artists.  To describe the structures of diversified contemporary art institutions, art works in public spaces, and dynamic networks and media platforms of contemporary art.

title: New Media Research Project
requirements: For students in MA Visual Culture Studies
description: This course will introduce students to new media production techniques, developing means of enhanced ‘essay-writing’ and report design formats, using image sequencing, text/image compilation and soundscape design. The aim of the course is to extend students’ technoliteracy and critical thinking skills in order that they may more astutely observe/ interact with/critically analyse still and moving image culture and sonic landscapes in artistic and commercial spaces. This course also provides a means for more technically literate students to undertake higher-level visual research projects, equivalent to more conventional written forms of research, thus drawing upon students own advanced production skills (where these exist). The course will encourage group projects so that creative skills and production management skills can be effectively matched to enhance team building for use in creative and other industries and applications. - Prerequisite: CLC5410

title: Comparative Studies of Asian Cinemas
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This is an in-depth subject analyzing contemporary, popular films from Japan, Hong Kong, and Greater China. In recent years films from this region have enjoyed international acclaim, not only from festivals and critics, but also a warm embrace worldwide. These films, along with those of S.Korea, have also spawned a number of Hollywood remakes. This course does not approach these as “national cinemas”, but as intertextual fields of great range and power. We will consider these films in light of their economic, industrials, technological, historical and international impact, leading to refl ections on media popularity: its structure, functions and processes. An operating premise of the course is that global film industries are rapidly consolidating, and while popular East Asian films remain distinctive, they do so in a marketplace of rising expectations, in storytelling, technical polish, and sophisticated promotion. While we take into account culturally special features, we will emphasize the ways these films engage with international frameworks of entertainment, and how these frameworks are changing. By the end of the course, you should be able to: 1) identify key features of East Asian popular films; 2) reflect clearly on these in relation to film industries and in conjunction with mainstream entertainment in the West; 3) show evidence of original thinking in framing questions of popularity in any medium (method of approach).

title: Fashion and Visuality
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course introduces students to the visualization and spectatorship of fashion culture. Our focus is to examine how fashion contributes to the visuality of image culture in the postmodern world, and how different notions of viewing mediate our sense of perception and the perspective system in everyday life. Not only do we explore the media representation of fashion in catwalk, photography, printing culture, popular music, video-making, film, dance, and stage performance, but also the interaction between the viewers and the viewed. Besides, we also study the history & theory of both Western and Chinese fashion as well as their interrelationships with body, identity, gender, class, and racial formations.

title: Immersive Media
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course explores the intersection/interface of the technological and the cultural, especially in relation to immersive (sometimes called ‘pervasive’) media in everyday life (in the use of mobile devices, PDAs, games and mobile games consoles, MPS players, interactive video screens in public spaces/shopping centres etc) and in the increasing use of interactivity in new media research and its creative applications in museum display and interactive and new media arts. The course is concerned to chart the development of new technocultural forms of literacy and their conceptual frameworks in cognitive and affective thought processes, in ‘information aesthetics’ and in distributed network theory. The aim is to understand the cultural implications of these developments as well as considering cultural and economic dimensions of the transformation of the ‘public sphere’ in, for example, the use of tracking and surveillance technologies for both security and market research activities.

title: Photomedia
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course is designed to trace the histories of photographic technologies, from the optical experiments of the early modern period (the camera obscura) to the emergent forms of mass entertainment in the nineteenth century (photography, the diorama and the panorama) to contemporary digital forms (the mobile phone photograph and the web-cam), from assumptions of analogical certainty to digital image manipulation. The course will consider the histories of techniques embedded in new tools of impage production (the metaphoric containment, for example, of the histories of painting, photography and printing in programs like Photoshop). The course will also consider the impact of new photomedia technologies on public access to archive resources in digitization projects and new systems of database design and indexing which image resources require. A consideration of new regimes of intellectual property will also be studied.

title: Visual Spectacles
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: Visual expressions have been frequently employed as tools for highlight and making something ‘special’. Through the process of creating spectacles, important messages are passed and images of authority confi rmed. With the rise of marketing economy and the rapid expansion of the media industry, the culture of spectacle has become a predominate part of the contemporary social experience. Starting from a historical review then moving toward the contemporary landscape, the course intends to provide an interdisciplinary examination of the mechanisms and ideological effects of the spectacle culture, with an emphasis on its impact on the social and cultural experiences of the locals.

title: Mass Media and the Transformation of Modern Society
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: The rise of mass media and modern social imaginaries has become the historical landmark of modernity. This course probes the interrelationship between mass media and social imaginaries in modern and post-modern ages. It traces the cultural consequences of various communication technologies and their relation to various conceptions of modern public spaces.In the light of Mark Poster’s theory on “the modes of information”, we will re-examine the historical development of the means of human communication, from the advent of print culture through to today’s digital and multi-media revolution. From this point of view, we try to point out the limits of the classical political theory on “public sphere” and provide a new direction for the reconsideration of modern social imaginaries and political culture.

title: Special Topics in Visual Culture Studies
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: The specifi c topics of this course vary from year to year. It will focus each time on a specifi c area or an issue of visual culture studies that is not covered in the regular visual culture studies programme. It aims to expand the scope of the programme to engaging students with ever emerging issues of visual literacy, spectatorship and new media arts and technologies. Because the themes of this course change from year to year, students are allowed to take this course more than once (not within the same term), and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take the same topic twice.

title: Visual Culture Theory
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course will introduce key techniques and methodologies used to analyze visual images in their various forms. Focusing on sources in both popular and high culture, in China, Hong Kong and the West, the course will examine aspects of thought and expression in self-image and identity, drawing upon cultural and aesthetic frameworks. The aim of the course is to equip students with high-level skills in image and cultural analysis and to understand current debates in intercultural visual studies. Key texts in the history and theory of global visual culture and visual studies will be subjected to close critical reading, drawing upon the insights of interdisciplinary approaches. Students will study art-historical, culturological and semiotic debates on the status of the image, inflected by recent developments in new media theory and ‘image science’ and gender and post-colonial studies.

title: Documentary Media: From Pre-cinema to Multi-Media Web Communities
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course aims at introducing history and theory of documentary in film, video, digital moving image, and new media including web-based archive and multi-media web communities. This is not a regular class on documentary film history. Rather, it explores the idea of documentation throughout history on various media. Realism as a mode of discourse will be re-examined. General concepts, aesthetics, ethics, practices and modes of documentary production will be introduced in lectures, followed up by discussions in tutorials. Research methods will also be discussed from various modes of documentary productions.

title: Visual Research Methods
requirements: For taught postgraduate students under Division of Cultural Studies
description: This course will introduce visual and sensory research methods to enable innovative research projects, drawing on frameworks in art history, visual anthropology, new media and cultural research. Students will learn techniques of formal and compositional analysis and study the history of objects and material and intangible culture. They will study questions of ethnographic method, observational and interview skills and visual data production, as well as ethics in fieldwork and in the use of images. The use of photography and video will be presented. Exercise in photo-elicitation, photo- documentation, and image-text and image-sound combination, (photo-essays, soundscape composition etc) will be undertaken as well as basic skills in video composition, videography and editing. New media techniques for image display will be studied as well as methods of archive research focusing on images, film, video and sound. Methods of image classification and interpretation will be introduced. The course will enhance students’ capacities in undertaking visually-focused research projects in community and professional contexts.
outcome:  To explain key distinctions between methodological approaches in visual research.  To identify key characteristics of good ethnographic research practice and techniques. To specify appropriate methods for visual observation and data collection in community-based and professional research contexts.  To recognize current debates and technological challenges in visual culture and new media.

title: User-Generated Content & Digital Culture
requirements: For students in MA in Intercultural Studies, MA in Cultural Management and MA in Visual Culture Studies.
description: This course is designed to introduce digital culture in web 2.0. It aims to engage learning of cultural activities that takes place in social networking setting. User-generated content is the main form of cultural text that we will examine in this course. The course begins with an understanding of basic theories in cultural studies. Students are expected to understand the fluid nature that culture becomes in the globally connected internet world. The course secondly introduces concepts that are recently developed in the study of user-generated content. It introduces emerging cultural concepts including creative labor, produsage, mashup, convergence, participatory creativity, networked community, remixed culture, copyleft and controlled regulation. The course also includes specific case discussion on how user-generated content is studied in the field of digital humanity. The approach of this course emphasizes lecture, discussion of reading materials, student presentation and applied media practice in student projects.

title: Meaning in Motion: Visual Culture in Dance
requirements: For students of MA in Intercultural Studies, MA in Cultural Management and MA in Visual Culture Studies.
description: “Meaning is present in every movement from the flutter of an eyelid to a space-splitting leap” (Terry, 1997). Dance has been regarded as an art form, an integral part of religion, culture, and community. It is also one of the prime subjects for cultural analysis.The course introduces students to the principles, concepts and practices found within dances, theater, and performing arts. Theatrical terminology, visual symbolism, ethnic identity, aesthetics, ideology and evolution of dance and theater in a variety of cultures and historical periods will be discussed, topics include: dance in relation to cultural identity or political power, semantics of movement and costumes, lighting and theater design analysis, globalization and media.In addition, this course broadens the scope of choreography analysis and practices. Activities include: Encoding and decoding dance movements, improvisations and self-expressions, theater and dance production, dance workshops.

title: City Imaginaries and Cinema Poetics
requirements: For students of MA in Intercultural Studies, MA in Cultural Management and MA in Visual Culture Studies.
description: This course examines the intersection of urban and cinematic experiences, it will investigate the images that define and brand cities, their implications to our future life, and it also encourages students to record and decipher their own experiences and imagine their living cities with self-produced short films essay that counteract emerging global cityscapes. Based on the theories of Gilles Deleuze, cinematic image as a thinking tool is used to see and reflect on the world and the experience of it. Certain poetic languages of cinema and urban theories are introduced as a plethora of expressive visual languages for students to examine their own thinking and experience in the city critically and reflectively.
outcome: Course activities involve:  1. Researching various urban narratives, whether mainstream or personal;  2. Observing with photography and mapping such narratives; 3. Critical and independent thinking on the meaning of those narrative with essays / digital journal;  4. Producing reflections and commentary through mini films. (5-10mins.)  Through active production of images, students learn through the logistic of production to move away from passive consumer of images to creative producer of visions, taking hold of lifestyle directions within the urban environment and communicate such ideas to others engagingly and effectively.
